Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they

nodes.body:
The main content of this pull request is: creating a definition `invOneSubPow` such that for any commutative ring `S` and natural number `d`, `invOneSubPow d : S⟦X⟧ˣ` has value `mk fun n => Nat.choose (d + n) d` and inverse `(1 - X) ^ (d + 1)`.

@kbuzzard @urkud @jcommelin @ChrisHughes24 @jjaassoonn
please mark as `awaiting-review` if it's ready for review

> please mark as `awaiting-review` if it's ready for review

Recently I have come up with an idea to change the contents of this pull request significantly. I will mark it as `awaiting-review` after I have made the change.

:v: FMLJohn can now approve this pull request. To approve and merge a pull request, simply reply with `bors r+`. More detailed instructions are available [here](https://bors.tech/documentation/getting-started/#reviewing-pull-requests).
bors r+

Build failed:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9117061369/job/25067083617)
bors r+

Pull request successfully merged into master.

Build succeeded:
  * [Build](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9118843148/job/25072866971)
  * [Check all files imported](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9118843148/job/25072866728)
  * [Lint style](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/actions/runs/9118843148/job/25072867224)

This is fine now. I've left some minor golfy comments; please fix them before merging!

bors d+
Sorry I took so long to get around to this.

This is fine now. I've left some minor golfy comments; please fix them before merging!

bors d+

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion · rw [show φ⁻¹ ^ (d + 1) = φ⁻¹ * (φ⁻¹ ^ d) by rfl, ← hd, ← PowerSeries.mul_inv_rev, pow_succ'] ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion ← Finset.sum_antidiagonal_choose_add]; exact (Nat.cast_sum (Finset.antidiagonal n) fun x ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [← one_sub_inv_pow_eq, pow_inv_eq_inv_pow] ```

**[lint-style]** reported by [reviewdog](https://github.com/reviewdog/reviewdog) :dog:
```suggestion rw [← one_sub_pow_inv_eq_invOneSubPow]; simp only [map_pow, map_sub, map_one, constantCoeff_X, ```
I think `induction'` will be deprecated sooner than later, can you use `induction` tactic instead
Same here, please use `induction` instead of `induction'`
the `show` here, should it be a separate lemma, it looks useful enough
same for `induction'` here

Why are we assuming `k` is a field here, the constant coefficient of `(1 - X)` is invertible, so `1 - X` as a power series is invertible in a commutative ring already. We have this in mathlib as well.

If possible, can you remove the `field` assumption whereever possible

```suggestion
  induction n with
  | zero => simp
  | succ n hn => simpa [Nat.sum_antidiagonal_succ] using hn
```
`simpa using h` is the same as `simp <;> simp at h <;> exact h` which is what you were doing.

There is already a variable S which is a Ring, which ends up being shadowed. Whilst this is probably an acceptable outcome, probably it would be better if you put all the `invUnitsSub` stuff in its own section with S declared to be a ring, and then you can declare your own R and S in your section. PS it's `Type*` not `Type _`.

```suggestion
-- Note that `mk 1` is the constant function `1` so the power series `1 + X + X^2 + ...`
theorem mk_one_pow_eq_mk_choose_add :
    (mk 1 : S⟦X⟧) ^ (d + 1) = (mk fun n => Nat.choose (d + n) d : S⟦X⟧):= by
```
I think adding `: S[[X]]` makes it more readable than adding `@`.

`simp` shows you what it can't get past by showing you its output. Here the problem is that it doesn't know that a good way to check that two functions are equal is to check they're equal on all inputs (because sometimes that's not the right direction so it's not a simp lemma). Here you want the `ext` tactic, and then `simp` can do the rest.
```suggestion
  | zero => ext; simp
```

This is long proof disguised as 3 lines using `;`. Here's a proof of about the same length which is easier to understand.
```
  | succ d hd =>
      ext n
      -- step 1: get rid of succ, use induction hypothesis, expand out
      rw [Nat.succ_eq_add_one, pow_add, hd, pow_one, mul_comm, coeff_mul]
      -- Now tidy up the mess `coeff_mul` made
      simp only [coeff_mk, Pi.one_apply, one_mul]
      -- Now cast down from `S` to `ℕ`.
      norm_cast
      congr
      -- now the key lemma rewrites the sensible way
      rw [Finset.sum_antidiagonal_choose_add]
      -- and now it's easy from a standard fact about binomial coefficients
      rw [← Nat.choose_succ_succ]
      congr
      -- ... (and commutativity and associativity of addition)
      exact add_right_comm d n 1
```

```suggestion
      ext n
      rw [Nat.succ_eq_add_one, pow_add, hd, pow_one, mul_comm, coeff_mul]
      simp_rw [coeff_mk, Pi.one_apply, one_mul]
      norm_cast
      congr
      rw [Finset.sum_antidiagonal_choose_add, ← Nat.choose_succ_succ,
        ← add_right_comm d n 1]
```

So you are in the middle of a subproof in the middle of a definition, and you suddenly realise that you'd be done if you knew `(mk 1) * (1 - X : S⟦X⟧) = 1`. So you should take this out as a lemma and prove it before writing the definition -- it might be useful again, so the proof shouldn't be hidden. Call it `PowerSeries.mk_one_mul_one_sub_X` or something, and then just rewrite it here and your proof will be clearer.
Aah! If you'd made `PowerSeries.mk_one_mul_one_sub_X` then this would just be `mul_comm` and then an application, saving you 6 lines here.
This surely cannot be the statement of the theorem you want. Why not use `PowerSeries.mk_one_mul_one_sub_X` to easily make the unit you want?
Why do we want this theorem? We already have `(invOneSubPow d).val_inv` and that's a shorter name than your theorem name. Same question for the next few theorems. But maybe they're useful?

Maybe it's just me, I think the doc string is a bit confusing. Maybe the following is better?
```
(1 + X + X^2 + ...) * (1 - X) = 1

Note that the power series `(1 + X + X^2 + ...)` is written as `mk 1` where `1` is the constant function so that `mk 1` is the power series with all coefficient equal to one.
```

```suggestion
  intro n
  by_cases hn : n = 0
  · subst hn
    simp only [coeff_zero_eq_constantCoeff, map_mul, map_sub, map_one, constantCoeff_X, sub_zero,
      one_mul, coeff_one, ↓reduceIte]
    rfl
  · rw [show n = n - 1 + 1 by exact (Nat.succ_pred hn).symm, sub_mul]
    simp
```
is a bit tidier

```suggestion
  val_inv := by
    rw [← mk_one_pow_eq_mk_choose_add, ← mul_pow, mk_one_mul_one_sub_eq_one, one_pow]
  inv_val := by
    rw [← mk_one_pow_eq_mk_choose_add, ← mul_pow, mul_comm, mk_one_mul_one_sub_eq_one, one_pow]
```

```suggestion
  simp [invOneSubPow, invUnitsSub]
```
The statement of this theorem could be cleaned up a bit using `Units.mkOfMulEqOne`

pullRequest.title: [Merged by Bors] - feat(RingTheory/PowerSeries/WellKnown): the power series of `1 / ((1 - x) ^ (d + 1))` with coefficients in a commutative ring `S`, where `d : ℕ`.
